case_name: M/s. Muller Phipps India Ltd. v. K.C. Sud

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 147 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated May 18, 1959, of the Labour Court, Delhi, in L.C.A. No. 53/1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the decision dated May 18, 1959, of the Labour Court, Delhi, in L.C.A. No. 53/1959.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by DAS GUPTA, J. on April 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. April 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Appeal against order of Labour Court, Delhi in application under s. 33C by respondent K. C. Sud.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is against an order of the Judge, Labour Court, Delhi, in an application under s. 33C of the Industrial Disputes Act by the respondent, K. C. Sud,

facts.text: Labour Court computed amount due to Sud by way of gratuity under award as Rs. 80.42 np.

anchor.surface_text: by which the Court computed the amount due to the petitioner by way of gratuity under an award to be Rs. 80.42 np. only.

facts.text: K. C. Sud was a workman of appellant company M/s. Muller Phipps India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Sud, who was a workman of the appellant company, M s. Muller Phipps  India  Ltd.

facts.text: Sud was retrenched by the company on January 31, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: was retrenched by the company on January 31, 1958.

facts.text: Reference on gratuity scheme for workmen pending before Industrial Tribunal at time of retrenchment, reference dated June 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: At that time a reference on the question of introduction of a gratuity scheme for the workmen of the company was pending before the Industrial Tribunal.

facts.text: Sud's application under S. 33A against retrenchment order failed.

anchor.surface_text: An application by Sud against this order of retrenchment under S. 33A failed.

facts.text: Industrial Tribunal made award framing gratuity scheme.

anchor.surface_text: In the reference above- mentioned the Court made an award framing a gratuity scheme

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: on death or incapacity, half month's basic salary/wages for each year of continuous service to employee/heirs.

anchor.surface_text: On the death of an employee while in the service of the company, or on his becoming physically or mentally incapable of further service, half a months basic salary or wages for each year of continuous service shall be paid to the disabled employees, or if he has died, to his heirs or legal representatives or assigns.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: on voluntary retirement or resignation after five years continuous service, half month's basic salary/wages for each year.

anchor.surface_text: On voluntary retirement or resignation of an employee, after five years continuous service, half a months basic salary or wages for each year of continuous service.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme: on termination of service by company, half month's basic salary/wages for each year of completed service.

anchor.surface_text: On termination of service by the company, half a months basic salary or wages for each year of completed service.

facts.text: Gratuity scheme applicable from June 28, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme was also made applicable with effect from the date on which the reference had been made, viz., June 28,1957.

facts.text: Sud made application under s. 33C claiming retrenchment amounts to termination of service entitling him to gratuity for completed service.

anchor.surface_text: It was on the basis of this award that Sud has made his application under s. 33C, his case being that as his retrenchment amounted to termination of service within the meaning of the award he was entitled to half a months basic salary for each year of completed service.

facts.text: Sud had completed two years of service, admitted.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly he had completed two years of service.

facts.text: Sud's basic wage at retrenchment was Rs. 80.42 np., not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: It is also not disputed that his basic wage at the time of retrenchment was Rs. 80.42 np.

facts.text: Sud received retrenchment compensation under s. 25F of Industrial Disputes Act.

anchor.surface_text: whether the respondent is entitled to recover gratuity under this scheme in addition to the compensation, he had admittedly received already in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F

facts.text: Company contended that gratuity is same as retrenchment compensation, allowing both would give double benefit.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this contention it is urged that the gratuity which the respondent claims is in essence the same thing as compensation for his retrenchment and to allow him gratuity in addition to retrenchment compensation -under s. 25F would be to give double benefit for the same event i.e., retrenchment.

facts.text: Award did not make specific provision for gratuity on retrenchment as such.

anchor.surface_text: the first thing that strikes us is that this award did not make any provision for gratuity for retrenchment as such.

facts.text: Workmen urged for distinct provision for retrenchment gratuity in statement of claim.

anchor.surface_text: It is important to notice that the workmen themselves in their statement of claim had urged for a distinct provision for retrenchment in addition to other modes of termination of service.

facts.text: Tribunal made no special provision for retrenchment but for three classes: death/incapacity, voluntary retirement/resignation, termination by company.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal however made no special provision for retrenchment but provided in its scheme of gratuity for three classes of cases, namely, (i) on the death of an employee or on his becoming physically or mentally incapable of further service, (ii) on voluntary retirement or resignation and (iii) on termination of service by the company.

facts.text: Court held that gratuity under award is in addition to retrenchment compensation under s.25F.

anchor.surface_text: We are bound to hold on an examination. of the award in the present case that the gratuity which the respondent claims on the basis of the award is distinct from and in addition to the retrenchment compensation he has received.

facts.text: Labour Court held respondent entitled to gratuity despite receiving s.25F compensation.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion therefore that the Tribunal was right in holding that the respondent is entitled to such gratuity even though he has already received payment of compensation for retrenchment

anchor.surface_text: This Court there considered in some detail the real nature and object of the retrenchment compensation 1 1960 2 S.C.R. 32. provided by s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act and the nature and object of a gratuity scheme as a retirement benefit. It pointed out that while gratuity is intended to help workmen after retirement to whatever cause the retirement may be due to, the retrenchment compensation is intended to give relief for the sudden and unexpected termination of employment by giving partial protection to the retrenched person and his family to tide over the hard period of unemployment.

concepts.interpretation: Gratuity as retirement benefit irrespective of cause; retrenchment compensation as relief for abrupt job loss and unemployment period.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: 2 S.C.R. 32. provided by s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act and the nature and object of a gratuity scheme as a retirement benefit. It pointed out

concepts.unlisted_label: Distinction between Gratuity and Retrenchment Compensation
concepts.unlisted_description: Gratuity rewards long service post-retirement; retrenchment compensation cushions sudden unemployment.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Court laid it down that the question as to whether retrenched workmen can claim the benefit of a gratuity scheme in addition to the retrenchment compensation under s. 25F or not would depend on the construction of the material terms of the scheme considered in the light of the provisions of s. 25F of the Act.

concepts.interpretation: Whether double benefit allowed depends on whether scheme frames gratuity as in lieu of or additional to s.25F compensation, examined by construing terms.

The scheme was also made applicable with effect from the date on which the reference had been made, viz., June 28,1957.

holdings.text: We are bound to hold on an examination of the award in the present case that the gratuity which the respondent claims on the basis of the award is distinct from and in addition to the retrenchment compensation he has received.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award lacks specific provision for retrenchment gratuity unlike Brahmachari case; retrenchment covered under general termination of service; applying Indian Hume Pipe test that entitlement to double benefit depends on scheme construction.

holdings.text: this award did not make any provision for gratuity for retrenchment as such.

anchor.surface_text: the first thing that strikes us is that this award did not make any provision for gratuity for retrenchment as such.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct examination of award text shows no distinct clause for retrenchment despite workmen urging one; contrasts with three general classes provided.

holdings.text: Retrenchment, it is true, will fall within the termination of service.

anchor.surface_text: Retrenchment, it is true, will fall within the termination of service. That, however, as is clear from the above cases, cannot by itself justify a conclusion that the gratuity that could be claimed under such a scheme in case of retrenchment was in lieu of retrenchment compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Retrenchment is a form of termination by company; accepted as within broad term per award language.

holdings.text: The reasonable conclusion from the scheme as drawn up is that the gratuity that could be claimed under this award by retrenched workmen because of the fact that retrenchment is also one kind of termination of service within the meaning of the award was intended to be in addition to the retrenchment compensation and not in lieu thereof.

anchor.surface_text: The reasonable conclusion from the scheme as drawn up is that the gratuity that could be claimed under this award by retrenched workmen because of the fact that retrenchment is also one kind of termination of service within the meaning of the award was intended to be in addition to the retrenchment compensation and not in lieu thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of separate retrenchment provision indicates intent for additional payment; distinguishes from cases with explicit retrenchment gratuity as substitute.

holdings.text: We are of opinion therefore that the Tribunal was right in holding that the respondent is entitled to such gratuity even though he has already received payment of compensation for retrenchment in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F of the Industrial Disputes Act.

Retrenchment, it is true, will fall within the termination of service. That, however, as is clear from the above cases, cannot by itself justify a conclusion that the gratuity that could be claimed under such a scheme in case of retrenchment was in lieu of retrenchment compensation.

We are of opinion therefore that the Tribunal was right in holding that the respondent is entitled to such gratuity even though he has already received payment of companypensation for retrenchment in accordance with the provisions of s. 25F of
